questions.question_text: Users are reporting performance issues when attempting to access the main fileshare server. Which of the following steps should a network administrator perform NEXT based on the network troubleshooting methodology?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Determine if anything has changed.

Based on the network troubleshooting methodology, after initial reports of performance issues, the next step a network administrator should perform is to determine if anything has changed on the network or within the system that could be causing the reported issues. Identifying recent changes can help narrow down the list of potential causes, such as configuration adjustments, software updates, or newly introduced hardware, which might be impacting the performance of the fileshare server. Understanding what has changed is a critical step before moving on to establishing theories of probable caus

Selected Answer: B
Determine if anything has changed = identify the problem

Selected Answer: B
Determine if anything has changed

Determining if anything has changed is an essential step in troubleshooting because changes in the network environment, configuration settings, or system updates can often lead to performance issues or connectivity problems. By identifying any recent changes, the administrator can narrow down potential causes and focus troubleshooting efforts more effectively.

This step involves asking questions and gathering information from users or other team members to understand if any modifications or updates have been made to the network infrastructure, server configuration, or client devices that could be contributing to the performance issues.

Once the administrator determines if anything has changed, they can proceed with establishing a theory of probable cause and implementing a fix or workaround to address the performance issues if necessary.

Therefore, B. Determine if anything has changed is the correct next step in the network troubleshooting methodology in this scenario.

Selected Answer: B
Determine if anything has changed is part of Step 1 which is where you would start when you first receive a report of a symptom such as slowness.

choices.D: Document all findings, actions, and lessons learned.
choices.A: Implement a fix to resolve the connectivity issues.
choices.C: Establish a theory of probable cause.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Routinely upgrade all network equipment firmware.

The penetration testers gained access by exploiting a known and fixed remote code execution vulnerability in the VPN appliance. The best preventive measure to avoid such incidents in the future is to routinely upgrade all network equipment firmware. Regularly updating firmware ensures that vulnerabilities, especially those that have been publicly disclosed and for which fixes are available, are patched. This reduces the attack surface and protects against known exploits.

Selected Answer: D
Firmware upgrades patch known vulnerabilities and exploits.

choices.D: Routinely upgrade all network equipment firmware.
choices.C: Create private VLANs for management plane traffic.
choices.B: Implement robust ACLs with explicit deny-all entries.
choices.A: Change default passwords on internet-facing hardware.

questions.question_text: A network administrator is implementing process changes based on recommendations following a recent penetration test. The testers used a method to gain access to the network that involved exploiting a publicly available and fixed remote code execution vulnerability in the VPN appliance. Which of the following should the administrator do to BEST prevent this from happening again?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Install an access switch in the annex and run fiber to the distribution switch.

The issue stems from the Cat 6 cable running a distance of 492ft (150m), which exceeds the maximum recommended length of 100 meters (approximately 328 feet) for Ethernet over copper cabling. This can cause slow speeds and intermittent connectivity due to signal degradation over the extended distance.

Selected Answer: B
The cable length is too long for Cat6 as highlighted by others

Selected Answer: B
no other cable choice would help in this situation. you would need fiber for that distance. increasing bandwidth would do nothing in this situation because the signal is barely getting to him due to attenuation.

option be because of the slow speeds and intermittent connectivity for a computer connected via a Cat 6 cable to a distribution switch located 492ft (150m) away. This distance exceeds the recommended maximum distance for Ethernet over copper cables like Cat 6.

choices.A: Increase the bandwidth allocation to the computer.
choices.C: Run a Cat 7 cable from the computer to the distribution switch.
choices.D: Enable the computer to support jumbo frames.
choices.B: Install an access switch in the annex and run fiber to the distribution switch.

questions.question_text: A technician is troubleshooting a computer issue for a user who works in a new annex of an office building. The user is reporting slow speeds and intermittent connectivity. The computer is connected via a Cat 6 cable to a distribution switch that is 492ft (150m) away. Which of the following should the technician implement to correct the issue?

discussion.content: remember to 'dick' the reset button lads. Very important.

I'm curious if anyone else has an opinion on this, but how would we know what the correct gateway is? There's no router here, and it doesn't mention if the switches are layer 3.. so we have to assume that the router (not pictured) is the correct gateway.
Alot of these PBQs vague asf

so assuming in the exam we are provided with windows and test results, we can eliminate a few devices simply based off the relative config. first id look at all the test results and see if there is any change (VLAN assignment, length, straight through or crossover cable etc). next id refer to each window and see the available commands using '?'. after that id work my way through to see if there is any mismatching values between each computer and each server. Ive had a question similar to this in my previous exam, and the easiest way to troubleshoot is a simple bottom to top approach.
I agree, there is no way I can see to troubleshoot this in its current state. More information is required.

comments.content: IDK, but at least we have an idea of where to look. Should be easy to figure out if that is the issue with the IPs and Subnet given

questions.question_text:
SIMULATION
-

A network technician needs to resolve some issues with a customer's SOHO network. The customer reports that some of the devices are not connecting to the network, while others appear to work as intended.


INSTRUCTIONS
-

Troubleshoot all the network components and review the cable test results by clicking on each device and cable.

Diagnose the appropriate component(s) by identifying any components with a problem and recommend a solution to correct each problem.

If at any time you would like to bring back the initial state of the simulation, please dick the Reset All button.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Link flapping: occurs when a network interface, such as a switch port, goes up and down repeatedly, as indicated by the syslog messages. The logs show the port (G1/10) going "DOWN" and then "UP" multiple times within a short time frame, which is a clear sign of link instability or "flapping."

Selected Answer: D
D. Link flapping

The syslog entries from the switch indicate that the link on port G1/10 is repeatedly going down and then coming back up in a short amount of time. This behavior is known as link flapping. Link flapping can be caused by various issues, such as faulty cables, bad ports, or misconfigured network equipment, leading to intermittent connectivity between devices.

questions.question_text:
A technician is troubleshooting intermittent connectivity between devices and viewing the following syslog entries from a switch:

21 Feb 2022 16:02:0231 NOTIFICATION %LINK-I-DOWN: G1/10
21 Feb 2022 16:02:0262 NOTIFICATION %LINK-I-UP: G1/10
21 Feb 2022 16:03:5321 NOTIFICATION %LINK-I-DOWN: G1/10
21 Feb 2022 16:03:7873 NOTIFICATION %LINK-I-UP: G1/10

Which of the following are these entries indicative of?
